definitions.definition: acceptable and appropriate in a particular situation
definitions.sensetop: fair to somebodyfair to somebody to do somethingfair on somebodyfair on somebody to do somethingit is fair to do somethingit is fair that…

examples.text: a **fair deal/wage/price**
The punishment was very fair.
In the end, a draw was a fair result.
I give you fair warning, I’m not always this generous.
We wanted to resolve this matter in a way that would be fair to her.
Was it really fair to him to ask him to do all the work?
examples.contextForm: fair to somebody to do something

examples.text: Moving to a new city wouldn't have been fair on the kids.
It's not fair on the students to keep changing the timetable.
examples.contextForm: fair on somebody to do something

examples.text: **It's only fair** to add that they were not told about the problem until the last minute.
examples.contextForm: it is fair to do something

examples.text: I think **it is fair to say that** they are pleased with this latest offer.
It's fair that they should give us something in return.
**To be fair**, she behaved better than we expected.
‘You should really have asked me first.’ ‘Right, okay, **fair comment**.’
I don't care what he thinks. It seems perfectly fair to me.
It's quite expensive, but I still think it's a fair price.
It's only fair to say that this is the first time she's heard about the problem.
It's a fair question, and it deserves to be taken seriously.
That doesn't seem quite fair.
To be fair, we hadn't really spent enough time on the job.
I don't think the sentence was very fair.
All we're asking for is a fair wage.

definitions.definition: treating everyone equally and according to the rules or law

examples.text: She has always been scrupulously fair.
They are fair and decent employers.
demands for a fairer distribution of wealth
his vision of a fairer, kinder society
The new tax is fairer than the old system.
We have to be fair to both players.
to receive a **fair trial**
For the first time, **free and fair elections** will be held.
**It's not fair!** He always gets more than me.
They are demanding a fairer distribution of the earth's resources.
I'll give you ten pounds each to make it fair.
It's hardly fair that I should be working while everyone else is enjoying themselves!
Everyone has the right to a fair trial.
It's important to be scrupulously fair when grading the final exam paper.
That seems fair to all sides.

definitions.definition: pale in colour

examples.text: a fair complexion
Kate had dark hair and fair skin.
She has long fair hair.
All her children are fair *(= they all have fair hair)*.

definitions.definition: quite large in number, size or amount

examples.text: A fair number of people came along.
There's been a **fair amount** of research on this topic.
a fair-sized town
We've still got **a fair bit** *(= quite a lot)* to do.
My birthday’s still a fair way off *(= it’s still a long time until my birthday)*.

definitions.definition: quite good

examples.text: There's **a fair chance** that we might win this time.
It's a fair bet that they won't turn up.
I have a fair idea of what happened.
His knowledge of French is only fair.
Scoring twenty points was a fair achievement.

definitions.definition: bright and not raining

examples.text: It was a fair and breezy day.
The day was set fair with the spring sun shining down.

definitions.definition: not too strong and blowing in the right direction

examples.text: They set sail with the first fair wind.

definitions.definition: beautiful

examples.text: a fair maiden

definitions.definition: in some situations any type of behaviour is acceptable to get what you want
used to tell somebody to be reasonable in their judgement of somebody/something

examples.text: Be fair! She didn't know you were coming.

definitions.definition: using dishonest methods if honest ones do not work

examples.text: She’s determined to win, by fair means or foul.

definitions.definition: a reasonable opportunity to show that you can do something

examples.text: I felt we weren't given a fair crack of the whip.

definitions.definition: used to say that an idea or suggestion seems reasonable

examples.text: ‘We'll meet at 8.’ ‘Fair enough.’
If you don't want to come, fair enough, but let Bill know.

definitions.definition: a fairly large number

examples.text: I've been there a fair few times.

definitions.definition: used to ask somebody to be reasonable

examples.text: I just wanted to say, ‘Hey mate, fair go!’

definitions.definition: (to allow somebody) the opportunity to give their opinion of something before deciding if they have done something wrong, often in court

examples.text: I'll see that you get a fair hearing.

definitions.definition: used to ask for fair treatment or to claim that a situation is fair

examples.text: Fair's fair—we were here first.
Fair's fair—you can't expect them to cancel everything just because you can't make it.
Come on, fair's fair—you’ve had your chance, now let me try.

definitions.definition: (to give somebody/get) fair treatment that gives you the same chance as somebody else

examples.text: Are minority students getting a fair shake at college?
We need a government that cares about equity and a fair go for all.

definitions.definition: (more than) an amount of something that is considered to be reasonable or acceptable

examples.text: He has more than his fair share of problems.
I've had my fair share of success in the past.

definitions.definition: not particularly good or bad

examples.text: ‘How are you feeling today?’ ‘Oh, fair to middling.’

definitions.definition: used by somebody who is caught doing something wrong, to say that they admit that they are wrong

wordOrigin: adjective Old English fæger ‘pleasing, attractive’, of Germanic origin; related to Old High German fagar.
